com.dsp

Class DspPage

  • java.lang.Object
    • HttpServlet
      • com.dsp.DspPage

  • public abstract class DspPage
extends HttpServlet
    This class is the default class that all DSP pages extend. When a page is written to extend another class then an object of this class still be created as the page object. Functions of this class are treated special in the DSP parser. Any arguments passed to functions which do not start with an underscore '_', will be converted to the proper type automatically. Functions that accept multiple arguments accept Object arrays. These functions call allow any number of arguments and the DSP parser will send all arguments as elements of the array.

    • Method Detail

      • abs

        public static int abs(int arg)
        Integer absolute value. Returns the absolute value of arg.

      • add

        public static int add(java.lang.Object[] args)
        Integer addition. Returns the summation of all arguments. Each argument is converted to an int type. An empty or null array arg evalutes to 0. Any null arguments are ignored.

      • and

        public static boolean and(java.lang.Object[] args)
        Logical And. Calculates the logical and of all arguments. Each argument is converted to a boolean as it is used. An empty or null array arg evaluates to 0. Note, this function cannot do short-circut evalation, as Java dose when you use the || operator.
        See Also:
        or()

      • base64Decode

        public static java.lang.String base64Decode(java.lang.String data)
        Decode a Base64 String. This decodes a String that has been encoded with Base64 encoding, as defined in RFC 1521.

      • base64Encode

        public static java.lang.String base64Encode(java.lang.String data)
        Encode a Base64 String. This encodes a String using Base64 encoding, as defined in RFC 1521.

      • bitAnd

        public static int bitAnd(java.lang.Object[] args)
        Bit-wise And. Calculates the bit-wise and of all arguments. Each argument is converted to an int as it is used. An empty or null array evaluates to 0.

      • bitOr

        public static int bitOr(java.lang.Object[] args)
        Bit-wise Or. Calculates the bit-wise or of all arguments. Each argument is converted to an int as it is used. An empty or null array arg evaluates to 0.

      • bitXor

        public static int bitXor(java.lang.Object[] args)
        Bit-wise Exclusive-Or. Calculates the bit-wise exclusive or of all arguments. Each argument is converted to an int as it is used. An empty or null array arg evaluates to 0.

      • concat

        public static java.lang.String concat(java.lang.Object[] args)
        Concatenates Strings. This simply concatenates the arguments and returns the String. Each argument is converted to a String as it is used. Null arguments convert to the empty String "". An empty or null array arg evaluates to the empty string "".

      • date

        public static java.lang.Object date(java.lang.Object[] args)
                             throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Deprecated. 
        Date Conversion and Extraction. This multipurpose function can convert a Date object to a String in several formats, or can extract parts of the date. This function only accepts one or two arg elements. If two, the first is the requested function to perform, and the second is converted to java.sql.Date. If one, the request is assumed to be "short". The following are the types of functions performed based on the request:
        Request (arg1)ReturnedTypeExample
        shortShort DateString2000-11-20
        longLong DateStringMonday, November 20, 2000
        sqlSQL DateString{d '2000-11-20'}
        yearYearInteger2000
        monthMonthInteger11
        dayDay of MonthInteger20
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

      • dateAdd

        public static java.sql.Date dateAdd(java.lang.Object[] args)
                             throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Add date units to a Date. This function adds years, months, weeks, or days to a Date. This function accepts either two or three arg elements. The first element is converted to a java.sql.Date. The second is converted to an int. The last if present is converted to a String and specifies the type of addition to perform. If only two elements are sent the type is assumed to be "days". Here are the allowed addition requests: year, years, month, months, week, weeks, day, or days.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

        public static java.sql.Date dateSub(java.lang.Object[] args)
                             throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Subtract date units from a Date. This function subtracts years, months, weeks, or days from a Date. This function accepts either two or three arg elements. The first element is converted to a java.sql.Date. The second is the value converted to an int. The last if present is converted to a String and specifies the type of subtraction to perform. If only two elements are sent the type is assumed to be "days". Here are the allowed subtraction requests: year, years, month, months, week, weeks, day, or days.

      • div

        public static int div(java.lang.Object[] args)
        Integer division. Returns the first argument divided by each of the reast. Each argument is converted to an int type. An empty or null array arg evalutes to 0. Any null arguments are ignored.

      • divRoundOff

        public static int divRoundOff(int i1,
              int i2)
                       throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Integer division with round-off. This works the similar to div(), except that when the resulting fractional part is 1/2 or greater the next higher integer (or lower in case of a negative result) is returned. Also, this only works with two arguments.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        See Also:
        div(Object[]), divRoundUp(int, int)

      • divRoundUp

        public static int divRoundUp(int i1,
             int i2)
                      throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Integer division with round-up. This works the similar to div(), except that when their would be any remainder the next higher integer (or lower in case of a negative result) is returned. Also, this only works with two arguments.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        See Also:
        div(Object[]), divRoundOff(int, int)

      • eq

        public boolean eq(java.lang.Object arg1,
         java.lang.Object arg2)
        Returns true if arg1 and arg2 are equals, false otherwise. Arg2 is converted to the same time as arg1, if the types to not match. If arg2 can't be converted the result is false. Case is ignored when comparing Strings.

      • execute

        public DspStatement execute(java.lang.String typeStr,
                   java.lang.Object obj)
                     throws DspException
        Execute a statement. The first word specifies the type of statement: "array", "dir", "scan", or "sql". If none of those are found the statement is assumed to be of type "sql". The db option to switch databases is allowed at the beginning of sql statements.
        Throws:
        DspException

      • executeGet1st

        public java.lang.Object executeGet1st(java.lang.String typeStr,
                             java.lang.Object obj)
                               throws DspException
        Execute a statement and return the first column of the first row if statement produces a result set. Otherwise, return the number of rows modified. The first word specifies the type of statement: "array", "dir", "scan", or "sql". If none of those are found the statement is assumed to be of type "sql". The db option to switch databases is allowed at the beginning of sql statements.
        Throws:
        DspException

      • html

        public static java.lang.String html(java.lang.String text)
        Converts the String to HTML format. It looks for certain characters and converts them to the proper HTML tags. If the String already contains HTML tags, these will be left intact. You will probably use this function heavily, unless you store HTML directly in your database. The following table lists the conversions that take place within this function:
        FromToConditions and Comments
        \r, \n, or \r\n<br> 
        \t&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
        <space><space>...&nbsp;...<space><space> means a space character
        &&amp; 
        ;&semi; 
        *<ul><li>Unordered list; must begin a line
        **...<ul><ul>...<li>Higher level lists; must begin a line
        #<ol><li>Ordered list; must begin a line
        ##...<ol><ol>...<li>Higher level lists; must begin a line
        ^<blockquote>Indented block; must begin a line
        ^^...<blockquote>
        <blockquote>...        		Higher level indents; must begin a line
        (c) or (C)&copy;©
        (r) or (R)&reg;®
        (tm) or (TM)<small><sub>TM</small></sub>TM
        (sm) or (SM)<small><sub>SM</small></sub>SM
        {&#123;To prevent DSP from parsing published pages
        }&#125;same as above

      • htmlChars

        public static java.lang.String htmlChars(java.lang.String text)
        Converts the String to HTML format. It looks for certain characters and converts them to the proper HTML tags. If the String already contains HTML tags, these will be left intact. You will probably use this function heavily, unless you store HTML directly in your database. The following table lists the conversions that take place within this function:
        FromToConditions and Comments
        (c) or (C)&copy;©
        (r) or (R)&reg;®
        (tm) or (TM)<small><sub>TM</small></sub>TM
        (sm) or (SM)<small><sub>SM</small></sub>SM
        {&#123;To prevent DSP from parsing published pages
        }&#125;same as above

      • instant

        public static java.lang.Object instant(java.lang.Object[] args)
                                throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                                       java.lang.NumberFormatException
        Deprecated. 
        Format Timestamp in various ways. This multipurpose function can convert a Timestamp object to a String in several formats. This function only accepts one or two arg elements. If two, the first is the requested function to perform, and the second is converted to java.sql.Time. If one, the request is assumed to be "short". The following are the types of functions performed based on the request:
        Request (arg1)ReturnedTypeExample
        shortShort TimestampString2000-11-20 12:13 PM
        longLong TimestampStringMonday, November 20, 2000 12:13:52.239 PM MST
        sqlSQL TimestampString{ts '2000-11-20 12:13:52.239 PM MST'}
        accessMS Access TimestampString#2000-11-20 12:13:56 PM#
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        java.lang.NumberFormatException

      • instantAccess

        public static java.lang.String instantAccess(java.sql.Timestamp date)
        Convert Timestamp to an MS Access SQL String. Converts the Timestamp to a String for use in an SQL statement when using Microsoft Access(tm). This is needed because MS Access, using the JDBC-ODBC bridge, doesn't support the standard JDBC Timestamp format.

      • instantAdd

        public static java.sql.Timestamp instantAdd(java.lang.Object[] args)
                                     throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                                            java.lang.NumberFormatException
        Add units of time to a Timestamp. Adds years, months, weeks, days, hours, minutes, seconds, milliseconds from Time. It accepts 2 or three members of args. The first is convert to Time. The second is the value to be added. The third, if present, is the units String: years, months, weeks, days, hours, mins, secs, msecs. If no third member is present, the units are assumed to be milliseconds.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        java.lang.NumberFormatException

      • multiplex

        public static java.lang.Object multiplex(java.lang.Object[] args)
                                  throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Return one of several arguments depending the first. The first argument is compared with each odd indexed argument. If a match is found then the following argument is returned. If no match is found then the last argument is return as the default, or null if there were an odd number of arguments. If the first argument is a string, then the comparisons by converting the objects to strings and and ignoring the case. Otherwise, Object.equals() is used for comparison and the programmer must ensure type and value match.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

        Not Equal. Return true if the two objects are not equal. This calls eq() and returns the boolean negative.

                                java.lang.String sub,
                                java.lang.String rep)
        Substring Replacer. For each instance of sub found in str, it is replaced by rep. The buffer argument itself is modifed and returned. This is faster than replace(), especially useful when called multiple times for various replacements.

      • sub

        public static int sub(java.lang.Object[] args)
        Integer Subtraction. Each argument is subtracted from the first. If no arguments are submitted then the result is 0. Any null arguments are ignored.

      • time

        public static java.lang.Object time(java.lang.Object[] args)
                             throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                                    java.lang.NumberFormatException
        Format Time in various ways. This multipurpose function can convert a Time object to a String in several formats, or extract parts of the date. This function only accepts one or two arg elements. If two, the first is the requested function to perform, and the second is converted to java.sql.Time. If one, the request is assumed to be "short". The following are the types of functions performed based on the request:
        Request (arg1)ReturnedTypeExample
        shortShort TimeString12:13 PM
        longLong TimeString12:13:52.239 PM
        sqlSQL TimeString{t '12:13:52.239 PM'}
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        java.lang.NumberFormatException

      • timeAdd

        public static java.sql.Time timeAdd(java.lang.Object[] args)
                             throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                                    java.lang.NumberFormatException
        Add units to Time. Adds hours, minutes, seconds, milliseconds to Time. It accepts 2 or three members of args. The first is convert to Time. The second is the value to be added. The third, if present, is the units String: hours, mins, secs, msecs. If no third member is present, the units are assumed to be seconds.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        java.lang.NumberFormatException

      • timeDiff

        public static java.lang.String timeDiff(java.sql.Timestamp time1,
                        java.sql.Timestamp time2)
        Retuns the difference between two Timestamps, as a String.

      • timeLong

        public static java.lang.String timeLong(java.sql.Time date)
        Convert Time to long String. Returns a String with the time in long format.

      • timeMil

        public static java.lang.String timeMil(java.sql.Time date)
        Convert Time to a String. Returns a String with the time in military format.

      • timeShort

        public static java.lang.String timeShort(java.sql.Time date)
        Convert Time to a short String. Returns a String with the time in short format.

      • timeSql

        public static java.lang.String timeSql(java.sql.Time date)
        Convert Time to SQL. Returns a String with the time encoded for use in an SQL statement.

      • timeSub

        public static java.sql.Time timeSub(java.lang.Object[] args)
                             throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                                    java.lang.NumberFormatException
        Subtract units of time from Time. Subtracts hours, minutes, seconds, milliseconds from Time. It accepts 2 or three members of args. The first is convert to Time. The second is the value to be subtracted. The third, if present, is the units String: hours, mins, secs, msecs. If no third member is present, the units are assumed to be seconds.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        java.lang.NumberFormatException

      • url

        public static java.lang.String url(java.lang.String value)
        Format data for use in a URL String. This function formats arg as a String with characters that are not allowed in a URL converted to %hex. Use this when you need to put a field value into an HTML URL, on the right side of the ? character.
        See Also:
        urlFull(String)

      • urlFull

        public static java.lang.String urlFull(java.lang.String value)
        Format data for use as a URL String. This function formats arg as a String with characters that are not allowed in a full URL converted to %hex. Use this when you need to format a String to be the entire URL.
        See Also:
        url(String)
